awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track G: Privacy-preserving Intrusion-resilient Secure Multiparty-computation-based Overlay (PISMO) for Secure and Resilient Communication Through 5G
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops the Privacy-preserving Intrusion-resilient Secure Multiparty-computation-based Overlay (PISMO) system for secure and private communication through existing, non-cooperative 5G infrastructure. PISMO transparently integrates into several widely employed commercial end-user applications such as messaging and content sharing via authoring tools, e.g., Microsoft Office, email, and web-browsing.  As several military, government, and critical infrastructure operations rely on such end-user applications, PISMO hardens them against threats. Considered threats range from unintended eavesdropping to sabotaging cyber-attacks. This is accomplished while using existing and affordable 5G communication infrastructure without trusting or cooperating with the 5G operator.  Deploying and commercializing the PISMO system contributes to achieving greater national security and protection of communication privacy, wherever such operations are carried out, nonetheless always operating in a secure and resilient, yet highly functional and maintainable manner.

The PISMO overlay consists of client software provisioned on 5G end devices and server software deployed in clouds on the Internet to form the backbone of PISMO; clients will connect via the 5G wireless network to the backend servers.  The project focuses on use-centric design & usability to converge the developed software components into an easily usable, deployable, and ultimately transitionable system that leverages modern cryptography (e.g., secure multi-party computation, private information retrieval, and identity-based encryption) and advanced resilience and reliability techniques for distributed systems and networks.  In this research, two user types are considered; an Administrator, who configures, deploys, monitors, and maintains the PISMO overlay, and an End-User operating the PISMO client on wireless 5G end devices.  The research concentrates on solutions to hard questions about configuring, deploying, and managing PISMO via three use cases applicable to (1) critical infrastructure operations, (2) government uses, and (3) military operations.  These use cases will lead to precise definitions of the human-facing components and procedures.  The project’s scope also considers deploying prototype implementations on testbeds in private and public clouds to perform user studies capturing user experience (UX) elements and features. The prototypes will enable the calibration of various automation opportunities that the system offers in support of the Administrator’s task to define settings and maintain functionality. Lastly, an integrated and deployed prototype solution will meaningfully and practically demonstrate the advances in usability, functionality, resilience, and maintainability that the research in this project provides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase 1 project aimed to refine a concept for a commercial product based on our research technologies and build a multidisciplinary team that could realize that concept. We followed the process advocated by the Convergence Accelerator curriculum to (1) refine our product concept through use-inspired research, (2) build a team with the domain knowledge and skills to advance the project, and (3) develop materials to market our vision to potential customers and collaborators.

Use-inspired research: Our use-inspired research focused on the challenges for military end users and security administrators in securing high-consequence communication. We interviewed individuals whose roles included battlefield communication systems integrator, military communications security custodian, secure communications equipment designer, network administrator, and military roles such as Navy ship captain and drone operator. The interviews elicited a number of insights about user needs, constraints imposed by military operational environments, and challenges of managing technologies in the field.

During our research synthesis phase, we consolidated information we had gathered from stakeholder interviews, identified key themes and patterns, and identified questions we needed to answer to make essential decisions about project direction. We developed two low-fidelity prototypes to help us define technology options for discussion among the team members and stakeholders. One prototype showed alternative system deployment architectures, enabling discussions about which architectures would be viable in which customer environments. The second prototype provided a mockup of a common military application, augmented with our security controls, enabling discussions about usability of features for different types of users.

The use-centric design process yielded two insights that changed the direction of our project: (1) military and intelligence community users are interested in hiding communication endpoints, but enterprise users are not; and (2) secure systems are easier to adopt when they look like familiar systems. The first insight led us to split our protection technologies into two separate products that target different customer organizations: Our pico Selective Share product allows customers to control the visibility of data within application documents and is valuable in both enterprise and military domains. Our second product, pico Conceal, hides communicating network endpoints and answers a need that is unique to military and intelligence missions.

The second insight led us to focus on providing pico Selective Share through a software development kit (SDK) to software developers. Rather than our developing a new application for end users, software developers can enhance existing or new applications with our pico Selective Share capability. End users are then able to use familiar applications with new security capabilities “under the hood.”

Team-building: The Phase 1 project helped us identify gaps in our team capabilities and enabled team building to support the project as we pursue Phase 2. Our Phase 2 proposal includes two new team members: Stephenson Stellar and Red Balloon Security. Stephenson Stellar operates a 5G testbed laboratory that will enable us to test and demonstrate our products in a realistic 5G environment. A red team from Red Balloon Security will help us access the cyber security of our products.

Storytelling and marketing: We followed the process advocated by the Convergence Accelerator curriculum to develop a pitch for the project and the planned products, a written “executive summary” sheet, and a 3-minute marketing video. We presented our pitch to the NSF review committee and delivered the executive summary and marketing video.

The principles we learned through the NSF Convergence Accelerator curriculum and our work in applying them to our project provided valuable training for all of the researchers involved.
